user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketBindAddress_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketBindAddress_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr)
{
    int                             os_result;
    socklen_t                       addrlen;
    const struct sockaddr *         sa;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    sa = (const struct sockaddr *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (sa->sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            addrlen = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in);
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            addrlen = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in6);
            break;
#endif
        default:
            addrlen = 0;
            break;
    }

    if (addrlen == 0)
    {
        return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
    }

    os_result = bind(impl->fd, sa, addrlen);
    if (os_result < 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("bind: %s\n", strerror(errno));
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketBindAddress_Impl:
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragment in OS_SocketBindAddress_Impl modifies a function parameter (neither the pointer variables token or Addr nor their values). Specific points: - impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token); only reads the object referred to by token via *token; it does not assign to token itself. Even if the macro indexes a table, that uses the value of *token and does not modify the parameter. - sa = (const struct sockaddr *)&Addr->AddrData; takes the address of a member of the object pointed to by Addr and stores it in a local pointer sa; this does not modify Addr. - The switch reads sa->sa_family and sets the local variable addrlen; no assignments to token or Addr occur. - bind(impl->fd, sa, addrlen) passes the local sa and does not modify the pointer parameters within this function. - Error handling and return statements do not modify parameters. Therefore there are no fragments that require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
